security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files describing a Go web framework. No executable code, scripts, network operations, or file system access detected. All code examples show legitimate Go patterns for building web APIs with standard security practices.

content.user_title: Build enterprise Go web APIs fast
content.value_statement: Building RESTful APIs in Go requires implementing authentication, caching, documentation, and real-time features from scratch. This framework provides all these enterprise features with a simple options-based API. Build production-ready APIs in minutes instead of hours.
actual_capabilities: Create RESTful APIs with options-based router configuration
Implement JWT authentication with token creation, validation, and refresh
Add server-sent events (SSE) for real-time client updates
Generate OpenAPI 3.0 documentation and Swagger UI automatically
Use built-in memory caching system with TTL and list operations
Apply middleware for CORS, rate limiting, request ID, and timeout
limitations: Runs on the server side only, not for client-side code
SSE is one-way, not full bidirectional WebSocket

use_cases.title: Enterprise API development
use_cases.description: Build production-ready REST APIs with built-in authentication, caching, documentation, and security features.

use_cases.title: Rapid API prototyping

use_cases.title: API documentation generation

prompt_templates.title: Basic API setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new Go REST API using Darkit Gin that exposes a /ping endpoint returning "pong" with the success response format.

prompt_templates.title: Authenticated routes
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Darkit Gin API with a public /login endpoint and a protected /profile endpoint that requires JWT authentication using a secret from environment variables.

prompt_templates.title: Caching implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to add caching to a Darkit Gin endpoint so that repeated requests within 5 minutes return cached responses instead of querying the database each time.

prompt_templates.title: OpenAPI docs
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Darkit Gin API with OpenAPI documentation enabled. Show how to add documentation annotations to a /users GET endpoint including summary, description, and response examples.

best_practices: Read JWT secrets and sensitive configuration from environment variables, never hardcode them
Set appropriate TTL values for cached data based on how frequently it changes
Apply rate limiting and use proper CORS origins in production environments
anti_patterns: Do not hardcode secrets or credentials in source code
Do not ignore error returns from cache or database operations
Do not forget to clear or invalidate cache when underlying data changes

faq.question: How does Darkit Gin differ from gin-gonic/gin?
faq.answer: Darkit Gin extends gin-gonic/gin with enterprise features like built-in JWT, SSE, caching, OpenAPI docs, and options-based configuration while remaining fully compatible.

faq.question: Can I use Darkit Gin with existing Gin projects?
faq.answer: Yes. Simply replace the import from github.com/gin-gonic/gin to github.com/darkit/gin. All existing routes and middleware continue to work.

faq.question: What authentication methods are supported?
faq.answer: The framework includes JWT authentication with token creation, validation, refresh, and role-based access control. OAuth 2.0 support is also available.

faq.question: How do I generate API documentation?
faq.answer: Enable OpenAPI with gin.WithOpenAPI() and add route annotations using gin.Summary(), gin.Tags(), gin.Response(). Access Swagger UI at the configured path.

faq.question: Is my data collected or stored externally?
faq.answer: No. This framework runs entirely in your application memory. It does not collect, store, or transmit any user data to external services.

faq.question: What should I do if something is not working?
faq.answer: Check the framework documentation at docs/darkit-gin for detailed guides. Enable debug mode with gin.WithGinMode("debug") to see detailed request logs.
